content.task: Put the verbs into the correct tense. You'll get individual feedback for typical mistakes.

incorrectAnswersList.incorrectAnswerFeedback: Remember to use 'do/does' when negating a full verb (speak).
You forgot the 'third person singular -s' for simple present (he).
Present progressive (am learning) is used for something that is going on right now. @present_perf_prog
Simple past (learned/learnt) is used if something is over and you just report it. @present_perf_prog

You're nearly there. It's great that you've used present perfect because the action (learning) connects past and present. But it's still going on and you talk about how long it has been going on: use present perfect progressive in such a case. (have/has been + ...ing)
Remember to use 'have' for I, you, we and they.

If you want to say that you've (never) done something at some point in your life, you need present perfect. (have/has + past participle) You've used simple past, which is for reporting about a specific event, typically including an exact time or date.
It's right now, so you must use present progressive (am/is/are + ...ing).
